1.text: Blot the cut ends of the ginger to remove extra moisture.

2.text: Place the ginger into a resealable plastic bag.

3.text: Tuck the sealed bag into the crisper drawer in your fridge.

4.text: Use fresh ginger within 4-6 weeks for the freshest taste.

6.text: Drop small spoonfuls of the grated ginger onto a lined baking sheet.

7.text: Freeze the ginger for 3-4 hours on the baking sheet.

8.text: Transfer the ginger from the baking sheet to an airtight container.

9.text: Mark the container and use frozen ginger within 6 months for the best flavor.

10.text: Take out a portion of frozen ginger whenever you need it for a recipe.

11.text: Peel the ginger and cut it into thin 1⁄16 to 1⁄8 in (1.6 to 3.2 mm) slices.

12.text: Sprinkle salt over the ginger and let it sit for about 30 minutes.

13.text: Boil 1 cup (240 mL) of rice vinegar and 5 tbsp (62 grams) of sugar.

14.text: Put the ginger into a glass jar and pour the rice vinegar on top.

15.text: Let the liquid cool to room temperature, then screw the jar’s lid on tightly.

16.text: Put the jar in the fridge and let it ferment for at least 1 week.

17.text: Keep the pickled ginger in the fridge and enjoy it within 4-6 weeks.

18.text: Preheat your oven to the lowest heat setting possible.

19.text: Arrange peeled, sliced ginger evenly on a baking sheet.

20.text: Bake the ginger for 1 hour at a time, flipping the slices every hour.

21.text: Remove the sheet from the oven once the ginger easily breaks apart.

22.text: Store the ginger in an airtight container in a cupboard or pantry.

23.text: Grind dried ginger in a coffee or spice grinder to make ground ginger.
